alttext: What is diabetes?
question: What is diabetes?
answer: Diabetes means high blood sugar, is a disease in which blood glucose (sugar) levels are higher than normal. As per ADA, if your fasting blood glucose is >126 mg/dL, or 2 hours after oral glucose tolerance test blood sugar is >200 mg/dL, or HbA1c is more than 6.5%. It is sufficient to say you are having diabetes. Glucose is the main source of energy for us and comes from diet and a pancreatic hormone insulin helps glucose to get into cells of our body. When our body either does not produce enough insulin or is unable to perform functions, blood sugar starts to rise. Diabetes if not controlled by proper management can cause serious health complications including heart disease, blindness, kidney failure, and lower-extremity amputations.

alttext: How do I know if I have diabetes? What are symptoms of diabetes?
question: How do I know if I have diabetes? What are symptoms of diabetes?
answer:
Although diabetes has various symptoms but most of the people remain asymptomatic in diabetes, hence called as 'silent killer'. Few symptoms of diabetes are as follows:-
A. Frequent urination or Nocturia (excessive urination in night)
B. Excessive thirst
C. Unexplained weight loss
D. Extreme hunger
E. Vision problems
F. Tingling or numbness in hands or feet
G. Tiredness and Fatigue
H. Delayed wound healing
I. More infections than usual

alttext: What's the difference between type 1 and type 2 diabetes?
question: What's the difference between type 1 and type 2 diabetes?
answer:
Diabetes has many types but mostly are divided into two types
A. Type 1 diabetes is basically an autoimmune disorder and a state of insulin deficiency, requiring lifelong insulin replacement therapy.
B. Type 2 diabetes is a metabolic disease, in which insulin actions become poor so patients need dietary advice, exercise and drugs to control blood sugar.

alttext: What should I do if I have diabetes? Do I need to see a diabetic doctor?
question: What should I do if I have diabetes? Do I need to see a diabetic doctor?
answer: If you are recently diagnosed with diabetes or have had diabetes for years, you should consult a diabetes doctor and understand about the disease. Diabetes is a metabolic disease and most of the time obesity, hypertension and high lipid levels are associated. All of these are risk factors for cardiovascular disease and need special care for patients. A diabetic doctor understands these things in a better way and provides specialized care to not only control blood sugar but to live a healthy life and prevent future complications.

alttext: What to do if my blood sugar is not controlled?
question: What to do if my blood sugar is not controlled?
answer: If your blood sugar is not controlled even after treatment, before revisiting your doctor or changing the doctor the first thing to think is why? It may be possible that you are not following diabetic diet and not doing proper physical activity or not taking medication at the right time. Second thing is that your disease needs higher medicine or the whole diagnosis may be wrong, in that case you need to consult your doctor.

alttext: What can I eat if I have diabetes?
question: What can I eat if I have diabetes?
answer:
Diabetes is not a punishment for a patient to keep him away from their favourite food, You can eat just about anything you want, and live a quality life but just keep one thing in mind. Any product with a high glycemic index (Glycemic index is the capacity of the food to raise the blood sugar after consumption) should be avoided.
Household sugar commonly known in India as 'chinni' and fruits with high fructose content like mango should not be consumed by a diabetic patient.
First of all before what and how to eat, we should know about how much calorie per day we need to consume. Besides counting calories, a simple advice from my point of view is a diabetic diet should have low carbs, good but low fat, high fiber, adequate protein from specially milk and veg sources.

alttext: What should I not eat for diabetes?
question: What should I not eat for diabetes?
answer: A diabetic patient should avoid sugar, sweets, juice, soft drinks, high fructose containing fruits like mango, fried items, junk food, fast foods, saturated and trans fat like dalda ghee, butter, cream, coconut oil, bakery products, polished rice, white bread, chocolate and alcohol.

alttext: Which fruits are best with diabetes?
question: Which fruits are best with diabetes?
answer: Fruits are high in fiber, low in fat and full of vitamins and minerals. It helps to protect against heart disease, cancer and certain stomach problems. Best fruits for diabetes is the most common question asked in my diabetes clinic. Before answering this question I would like to explain what is glycemic index - Glycemic index is the capacity of the food to raise the blood sugar after consumption. Fruits having low glycemic index are safe in deabetes like apples, guava, pears, oranges, peaches, apricots and berries. Some fruits like mangoes have a very high amount of fructose which should be avoided in diabetes. Some fruits should be consumed in limited quantities like papaya, watermelon etc.

alttext: I am a diabetes patient. What should my blood sugar be?
question: I am a diabetes patient. What should my blood sugar be?
answer:
The American Diabetes Association recommends glycemic targets for diabetic patients.
Fasting blood sugar (before meal) - 80-130 mg/dL
And postprandial 2 hrs (2 hours after meal) - less than 180 mg/dL

alttext: How to know my diabetes is under control?
question: How to know my diabetes is under control?
answer:
Every diabetic patient on treatment needs to do self monitoring of blood glucose to know the blood sugar level. You should check your blood sugar in fasting state at least once a week and 2 hours after meals at least 3 times in a week.
The American Diabetes Association recommends glycemic targets for diabetic patients.
A. Fasting blood sugar (before meal) - 80-130 mg/dL
B. Postprandial 2 hrs (2 hours after meal) - less than 180 mg/dL
C. HbA1c level - <7.0%

alttext: What is an HbA1c?
question: What is an HbA1c?
answer: HbA1c is a lab test which tells the 3 months average of your blood sugars. It is done to check whether your diabetes is in control or not. For a non-diabetic patient it must be less than 5.7 (As per ADA) and for diabetic patients it is advisable to keep HbA1c less than 7.0 to reduce the risk of future complications.

alttext: If it is sugar free, I can eat as much as I want, right?
question: If it is sugar free, I can eat as much as I want, right?
answer: Let's understand what sugarfree means - non-carbohydrate sweeteners, these are special chemicals which are sweet in test but they don't have glucose/fructose or sucrose, so basically known as sugar free sweeteners. Some are approved to use for diabetic population like sucralose (in market it is known as sugar free natura) but one thing to keep in mind is that every food item has calorie and if you are eating anything in large quantity with added sugar free means you are taking high amount of calorie which is not good for a diabetic patient. So you can use sugar free in very limited quantities to make your food sweet when necessary... Remember, moderation is the key and with diabetes... you need to be extra careful.

alttext: What is prediabetes?
question: What is prediabetes?
answer:
Prediabetes means your blood sugar is high but not enough to diagnose as diabetes. As per ADA if your fasting blood sugar is 100-125 mg/dL and HbA1c is 5.7-6.4, you are considered as prediabetes.
Prediabetes is basically an early stage of type 2 diabetes, need dietary restrictions and physical exercise to prevention of diabetes and some obese prediabetic patients need metformin. In simple terms, adapting to a healthy and active lifestyle.

alttext: What is insulin?
question: What is insulin?
answer: Insulin is a hormone produced by pancreas in the body. Its main function is to promote uptake of glucose by cells, and keep sugar under control. If a normal person consumed excess amounts of glucose or sugar or sweets, then all the glucose in the blood entered into cells by the help of insulin and kept the blood sugar in normal level.

alttext: How to keep insulin at home?
question: How to keep insulin at home?
answer: Insulin should be kept in freeze at a temperature between 2-8 degree centigrade.

alttext: How to take insulin?
question: How to take insulin?
answer: Insulin should be taken as a subcutaneous injection over abdomen, thigh and arm. It can be self-administered by a patient and modern needles are almost painless.

alttext: Where should you not inject insulin?
question: Where should you not inject insulin?
answer: Do not inject near joints, the groin area, the navel, the middle of the abdomen, or scar tissue. You will also need to rotate, or switch, your injection sites. If you use the same injection site over and over again, you may develop hardened areas under your skin that keep the insulin from working properly.

alttext: Can you reuse needles for insulin?
question: Can you reuse needles for insulin?
answer: Some people with diabetes use their insulin syringes and lancets more than once to save money. But makers of syringes and lancets do not recommend using them more than once. Talk with your doctor before reusing these items.

alttext: I am obese and have diabetes, how to lose weight?
question: I am obese and have diabetes, how to lose weight?
answer: Obese diabetics need special care for their weight management, first they should consult to a diabetes doctor, ask in detail about their diet and physical activity plan. These types of patients need special diabetic medicine to control their weight and some of diabetic medicine should be avoided which may increase their weight.

alttext: I am a lean thin diabetic, how do I gain weight?
question: I am a lean thin diabetic, how do I gain weight?
answer: All type 2 Diabetic are not Obese, these types of diabetic patients need special care for their blood sugar control and weight, first they should consult to a diabetes doctor, ask in detail about their diet and physical activity plan. These types of patients need special diabetic medicine to increase their weight and some of diabetic medicine should be avoided which may reduce their weight.

alttext: What if I don't take treatment for diabetes?
question: What if I don't take treatment for diabetes?
answer: A diabetic patient should be treated for blood sugar control and associated illness like BP and cholesterol otherwise he can get trouble in form of blockage of blood vessels, resulting in heart attack, stroke (paralysis), blindness (retinopathy), kidney damage (nephropathy), and neuropathy.

alttext: How to prevent chances of heart attack or stroke in diabetes?
question: How to prevent chances of heart attack or stroke in diabetes?
answer: A diabetic patient need special care for this issue, should control blood sugar, BP and cholesterol according to guidelines and if there is high risk of ASCVD or established ASCVD needed to be managed with special drugs for their blood sugar control and aspirin (blood thinner) may be added as and when required.

alttext: How to check for diabetes complications?
question: How to check for diabetes complications?
answer: A diabetic patient needs to be evaluated once in a year for their diabetic complications to diagnose early and manage complications. ECG, Lipid profile, Renal functions, Urine for proteinuria, Fundus examination and foot examination must be done at least once in a year.

alttext: How to identify gestational diabetes?
question: How to identify gestational diabetes?
answer: Some women during pregnancy may develop this type of diabetes, as placental factors may interfere with insulin action in the body. Every pregnant woman should be evaluated for routine blood sugar in the first ante-natal visit and oral glucose tolerance test in 20-24 weeks for diagnosis of gestational diabetes. Criteria for diagnosis are different from type 2 DM.

alttext: What are the signs that my blood sugar is too low? And what to do?
question: What are the signs that my blood sugar is too low? And what to do?
answer:
Low blood sugar means hypoglycemia, symptoms of low blood sugar are as follows:-
A. Sweating
B. Ghabarahat
C. Dizziness or lightheadedness
D. Extreme Hunger
E. Increase heart beat
Whenever a diabetic patient feels these symptoms he should check blood sugar immediately. If your blood sugar is below 70 mg/dL, treat yourself right away.
Immediately consume simple sugar at home 15gm (2 teaspoon) plain or dissolved in water. Or anything available with sugar or glucose should be consumed. Be careful not to eat too much. This can cause high blood sugar and weight gain.
Assess the symptoms and Check your blood sugar again after 15 minutes.
If you do not feel better in 15 minutes and your blood sugar is still lower than 70 mg/dL eat another snack with 15g of carbohydrates or simple sugar or glucose.
After that consult your doctor as soon as possible, and your medication should be revised.

alttext: What are the signs that my blood sugar is too high? What to do?
question: What are the signs that my blood sugar is too high? What to do?
answer:
If your blood sugar level is too high, known as hyperglycemia. Following symptoms may be there:-
A. frequent urination
B. Increased thirst/dehydration
C. Fatigue or Weakness
When your blood sugar level gets too high - known as hyperglycemia or high blood glucose - the quickest way to reduce it is to take fast-acting insulin, but most of the time consult your doctor and revise your medications.

alttext: Can I keep Ramadan with diabetes?
question: Can I keep Ramadan with diabetes?
answer: Fasting in diabetes is not advisable as patients on drugs needed regular meals as per their diet plan, but India is a religious country and most of the people keep fast according to their belief, so in diabetes if someone want to do fast he can perform but to be avoid some drugs or changing time of medication is advisable to prevent hypoglycemia.

alttext: Can diabetics drink alcohol?
question: Can diabetics drink alcohol?
answer: No, Never, alcohol must be avoided, not beneficial for their health.

alttext: Can I get rid of diabetes? Will it ever go away?
question: Can I get rid of diabetes? Will it ever go away?
answer: No, Once you are diagnosed with type 1 or type 2 diabetes, you have it for the rest of your life. To stay healthy, keep your blood sugar, blood pressure, and cholesterol under good conntrol. To do so, eat healthy, be physically active, and take your prescribed medications. Also get the tests and checks you need to detect complications early and treat them aggressively.

alttext: Future of Diabetes management
question: Future of Diabetes management.
answer: Scientists, Researchers and Doctors are working continuously to know more about diabetes, newer drugs and therapies. Nasal insulins are in pipeline and hope for beta cell transplant will be available in near future and type 1 diabetes may get a permanent cure if successful. Some drugs for type 2 DM like GLP-1 RA, which are very costly in India will become more affordable.
